discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
man ping command says,
-c count -> Stop after sending count ECHO_REQUEST packets. With deadline option, ping waits for count ECHO_REPLY packets, until the timeout expires.
So Answer A is correct, "determine active hosts on the network"

choices.A: Determine active hosts on the network.
choices.D: Scan the system on the most used ports.
choices.B: Set the TTL of ping packets for stealth.
choices.C: Fill the ARP table of the networked devices.

questions.question_text: Which of the following should a penetration tester consider FIRST when engaging in a penetration test in a cloud environment?

choices.C: The geographical location where the cloud services are running
choices.B: Whether the specific cloud services are being used by the application
choices.A: Whether the cloud service provider allows the penetration tester to test the environment
choices.D: Whether the country where the cloud service is based has any impeding laws

discussion.content: Think its A

Selected Answer: A
I stick with A

I'm torn between A and D. D because p. 35 of the Pearson cert guide. "local restrictions" section talks about how some pentesters have been arrested for violating local laws.

I'm leaning towards A though...

Selected Answer: A
Looks good to me

Selected Answer: A
Prior to testing in the cloud, the team will need to obtain the proper permissions from the provider and determine what type of testing will be allowed

Selected Answer: A
I found this on CertMarter from Comptia:
Prior to testing in the cloud, the team will need to obtain the proper permissions from the provider and determine what type of testing will be allowed. For example, testing might include virtual machines, and any application programming interfaces (API). In addition, the team will need to get a complete understanding of what is hosted, and how the cloud is used, so they can properly identify points of weakness. However, even with permission, the team needs to understand that some portions (or some testing) may simply be off limits.

Answer is A. 
C & D are basically the same answer anyways.

Selected Answer: A
correct answer is A
It should be A
the answer should be A

questions.question_text: A penetration tester who is conducting a web-application test discovers a clickjacking vulnerability associated with a login page to financial data. Which of the following should the tester do with this information to make this a successful exploit?

discussion.content:
BeEF has an active community supporting it â€“ the developers release updates and new features monthly. BeEF is free, open-source, and a popular tool in the web security world. Integrating the clickjacking tool into BeEF is a good way to distribute the tool to a lot of security professionals who would find it most useful.

Practical Clickjacking with BeEF 
Brigette Lundeen Center for Secure and Dependable Systems University of Idaho brigette.lundeen@gmail.com
Brigette Lundeen Center for Secure and Dependable Systems University of Idaho brigette.lundeen@gmail.com

Answer is definitely A
https://owasp.org/www-community/attacks/Clickjacking

A is correct.
https://www.acunetix.com/blog/articles/clickjacking-blind-xss/

questions.question_text:
A company that requires minimal disruption to its daily activities needs a penetration tester to perform information gathering around the company's web presence.
Which of the following would the tester find MOST helpful in the initial information-gathering steps? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: I'll go with D & F since it's the pentester's initial approach - info gathering and minimal disruption is a required.

Selected Answer: DF
"Web Presense" "initial information gathering" I am going with Search engines for company website and also shodan... both of these are passive recon.
A and D

Selected Answer: DF
D F That's correct.

Selected Answer: DF
Question say: perform information gathering around the company's web presence.

Selected Answer: AD
shodan falls under internet search engines and you would probably want to start with figuring out the IP and subdomains and then checking google and other search engines (shodan) using advanced searches. I would go with A and D
Shodan and search engines would be the best start for intelligence gathering imo
im going A and E, the rest you can do passively not even touching the site there for there is minimal issues.
I think this should be A and F

choices.D: Inform the customer immediately about the backdoor

when it comes to finding prior attacks always inform the client.

questions.question_text: A penetration tester discovers that a web server within the scope of the engagement has already been compromised with a backdoor. Which of the following should the penetration tester do NEXT?
